title: Collages Before College
text:
This was the first project I made with Procreate! I made this series of collages as graduation gifts to my hometown friends. It’s hard to believe that two year has already passed!
Feel free to click through the collages!

title: A Sort of How-To to Hooking Up and Hookup Culture + Some Hookup Reminders
text:
I created this zine titled, “A Sort of How-To to Hooking Up and Hookup Culture + Some Hookup Reminders” for my Sex, Love, and Romance course during the spring quarter of my freshman year. After observing how many of my peers were engaging in hookup culture, I realized how much knowledge—emotional, physical, and cultural—is needed to navigate it thoughtfully. This zine became a way for me to process and make sense of that behavior, especially as I adjusted to a new environment and social landscape.
Click through the pages!

title: Campus Involvement
text:
I am currently involved in several environmental organizations across campus.
Over the course of my second year at UCSB, I interned with Your Children’s Trees, a community-centered organization dedicated to environmental restoration through tree planting.
As an intern, I actively participated in tree planting initiatives at key ecological and community sites, including Ellwood Butterfly Grove, Ellwood Mesa, North Campus Open Space, Isla Vista Elementary School, and private properties in Isla Vista.
In addition to hands-on restoration work, I also helped engage the local community by representing Your Children’s Trees at elementary school Science Nights. These events gave us the opportunity to share our knowledge of native trees, ecology, and climate resilience with students and families in a fun, accessible way.








Me and other YCT members conducting tree maintenance







Me and other YCT members planting a tree and setting up a tree gator







Me and other YCT members carrying irrigation piping





Additionally, I have been involved in Sprout Up at UCSB as an instructor. UCSB is home to the largest chapter of Sprout Up dedicated to providing environmental education to first and second graders across Goleta. Alongside my teaching team, I introduced topics such as waste management, water conservation, and bee pollination, helping young students build a foundation in sustainability and environmental awareness.








Sprout Up Fall 2024







Sprout Up Fall 2024







Sprout Up Winter 2024

title: My Gallery
text:
Welcome to my gallery!
I created an interactive representation of the art I’ve made since entering college. Since moving to Santa Barbara, my primary medium has been Procreate, thanks to its versatility and ease of use—especially important given the limited space in my college apartment to store acrylic paints and canvases. I’ve completed a wide range of projects across different courses, and this felt like the perfect opportunity to showcase that creative work in one place.
Click on each piece to learn more about my projects!











What is Procreate?

title: Women as Mothers of the Economy
text: I created this piece, titled “Women as Mothers of the Economy,” as my final project for my Introduction to Economics course during the past winter quarter. For our final assignment, we were encouraged to explore a topic of our choice, and I chose to focus on women’s contributions to the economy—both in formal labor markets and through informal, often undervalued work like caregiving and domestic labor. This project was a meaningful opportunity to honor the economic roles of the women who came before me. Using a family tree format to visualize their impact, I applied a feminist lens to deepen my understanding of economic systems.

title: Stress Maps
text: This is my most recent project, titled “Stress Maps,” which I created for my Environmental Statistics course. For the assignment, we were asked to design an affective visualization based on personal data collected throughout the quarter. I centered my project around the question: “Do I leave campus more often when I feel stressed?” My response variable was my daily stress level, and my predictor variables included the number of assignments and social plans each day, the purpose of my travel off campus, and my method of transportation. This project allowed me to visualize how academic and social pressures influence my movement patterns and emotional well-being.

title: Hair Guide for Sustainable Engagement in the Hair Economy
text:
For my ENV S 40 course, Critical Thinking and Evidence-Based Reasoning for the Environment, I created a zine titled “Hair Guide for Sustainable Engagement in the Hair Economy”, which explores the environmental impact of synthetic hair commonly used in protective styles by Black women. This project investigates how synthetic hair—produced from plastic—contributes to pollution through toxic chemical emissions during manufacturing and waste accumulation after use.
While synthetic hair is often chosen for its affordability and versatility, its environmental cost is rarely discussed. My goal with this zine was to raise awareness about the ecological footprint of synthetic hair, without vilifying the cultural significance of protective styling. I also included accessible, affordable alternatives and sustainable practices to empower individuals to make informed choices that support both personal expression and environmental health.
Feel free to click through the pages!

title: Samantha Woods
text: Hi! My name is Samantha Woods (I go by Sam). I am currently a second-year undergraduate student at UCSB, majoring in Environmental Studies and minoring in Feminist Studies.

title: Black People Don’t Do That: Cannon Events of Black Children
text:
This is the first zine I ever made! Titled “Black People Don’t Do That: Canon Events of Black Children,” I created it as the final project for my first Feminist Studies course, Women of Color, which I took during the summer before my freshman year. The zine serves as a personal reflection on my experience growing up as a Black child, exploring the formative, often unspoken moments—what I call “canon events”—that shape identity, perception, and belonging.
Don’t forget to click through the pages!
